column6: To agree is to have the same opinion or belief as another person.

column6: A duck is a small water bird.

column6: A secret is something that you do not tell other people.

column6: To smell something means to use your nose to sense it.

column6: If something is worse, it is of poorer quality than another thing.

column6: A cloud is a group of water drops in the sky.

column6: To describe is to say or write what someone or something is like.

column6: Ever means at any time.

column6: To fail means you do not succeed in what you try to do.

column6: A grade is a score or mark given to someone’s work.

column6: A library is a place where you go to read books.

column6: I like taking photographs.

column6: A planet is a large round thing in space.

column6: A report is something someone writes for school or work.

column6: An object’s shape is the arrangement of its sides and surfaces.

column6: To solve something is to find an answer to it.
column7: All the students could easily solve the math problem.

column6: If something happens suddenly, it happens quickly and unexpectedly.
column7: I was surprised when my friends suddenly shouted, “Happy birthday!”

column6: To suppose is to guess.

column6: To understand something you need to know what it means.

column6: When a thing is appropriate, it is right or normal.

column6: To avoid something is to stay away from it.

column6: To behave is to act in a particular way, especially to be good.

column6: When someone is calm, they do not get excited or upset.

column6: Concern is a feeling of worry.

column6: If you expect something to happen, you believe it will happen.

column6: When something happens frequently, it happens often.

column6: To punish means to make someone suffer for breaking the rules or laws.

column6: An adult is a person who is more than 18 years old.

column6: Age is how many years someone has lived.

column6: When something is bad, it is not good.
column7: She is unhappy because she had a bad day.

column6: Balance is when two or more things are equal.

column6: A bike is a vehicle with two wheels powered by a human.

column6: When something is fun, it is enjoyable.

column6: A heart is an organ that keeps the body alive.

column6: A bilingual person can speak two languages.

column6: Disgust is a feeling of distaste and anger caused by something rude or unpleasant.

column6: Something fashionable is what people like to wear and do now.

column6: Spoken language is what we say.

column6: Sport involves games like running, jumping, football, and tennis.

column6: You are surprised when something unexpected happens.

column6: When you are tense, you are not comfortable and feel unhappy.

column6: People or things familiar to you are those you know well.

column6: A friend is someone a person knows and likes spending time with.

column6: To help is to do something that makes something easier for someone else.

column6: A hospital is where sick or hurt people receive care or treatment.

column6: To guard something is to take care of it.

column6: The image of something is a picture of it.

column6: To remain somewhere is to stay there.

column6: To rest is to stop being active while the body gets back its strength.

column6: If two things are separate, they are not together.

column6: A site is a place.

column6: A tail is a part of an animal’s body that sticks out from its rear or back.

column6: Trouble is a problem or a difficulty.

column6: To advertise is to describe or draw attention to a product or event by using a public medium.

column6: If someone is aware, they know that something or a situation exists.

column6: A battery is an object placed inside something to supply it with electricity.

column6: Black is the darkest color.

column6: A city is a place where a lot of people live.

column6: To clean is to make something neat and tidy.

column6: A country is an area of land with the same government and laws.

column6: If something is electric, it uses electricity.

column6: A street is a road in a city or village.

column6: A person who is alone is not with another person.

column6: An artist is a person who paints, draws, or makes sculptures.

column6: Someone’s attitude is the way they feel and think.

column6: Nationality is an identity based on the nation from which you come.
column7: His nationality is German, but he speaks French, Spanish, and Korean.

column6: A patriot is someone who loves, supports, and defends their country.
column7: Every year, young patriots join their countries’ militaries.

column6: To prosecute someone means to take legal action against them.
column7: They were prosecuted for fishing in the river without a permit.

column6: If something is racial, then it is related to a race or races.
column7: The differences between racial groups are physical characteristics and culture.

column6: If something is solemn, then it is serious and honest.
column7: The professor preferred a solemn relationship between him and his students.

column6: Solidarity is a union formed from common responsibilities or interests.
column7: All the citizens came together in a show of solidarity to create change.

column6: Tact is the ability to avoid offending people when dealing with problems.
column7: Since both sides would not agree, it required someone with tact to make peace.

column6: To undermine someone means to betray them or weaken their efforts or authority.
column7: The documents helped to undermine the workers’ trust in their bosses’ honesty.

column6: To constrain something means to limit its development.
column7: Jim cannot join us because he is constrained by previous plans.

column6: A depot is a bus or train station.
column7: He waited for his mother to arrive at the depot.

column6: To emulate people means to imitate them because they are greatly admired.
column7: As a small boy, he always tried to emulate his big brother.

column6: The forefinger is the finger between one’s thumb and middle finger.
column7: He shouted, “There it is!” and pointed with his forefinger.

column6: The guts are all the organs inside a person or animal.
column7: The doctor can tell you every process that happens in one’s guts.

column6: When something is inherent, it is a natural part of something else.
column7: Sweating is an inherent bodily function when exercising.

column6: To intimidate means to frighten others.
column7: My dad intimidates my friends whenever they visit.

column6: A janitor is a person who makes repairs and takes care of a building.
column7: The school janitor cleaned up the messy cafeteria.

column6: When something is moist, it is slightly wet.
column7: The ground is still moist from the rain last night.

column6: Nope is an informal way of saying “no.”
column7: He asked if I had any money, and I had to say, “Nope.”

column6: To prod means to push someone or something with a finger or pointed object.
column7: The bully prodded me in the chest with her finger.

column6: A ransom is a sum of money paid to a kidnapper to set the person free.
column7: He kidnapped the prince and demanded $1 million as a ransom.

column6: To restrain someone or something means to use physical strength to stop them.
column7: Mike restrained Allen from reaching the door.

column6: Saliva is the watery liquid in people’s mouths that helps in digestion.
column7: The baby could not keep the saliva from dripping out of its mouth.

column6: To spit means to force liquid from one’s mouth.
column7: He emerged from the pool and spit water from his mouth.

column6: To sprint means to run very fast over a short distance.
column7: The kids didn’t want to be late to class, so they sprinted to the bus stop.

column6: A stunt is something that is done in order to get attention or publicity.
column7: The man jumped over the cars as a promotional stunt.

column6: When people are tolerant, they are respectful of others’ rights and beliefs.
column7: The tolerant leader thought that everyone was equal regardless of race.

column6: A vampire is a fictional monster that sleeps in a coffin and sucks people’s blood.
column7: The vampire snuck up on the woman and bit her neck.

column6: To yawn means to open one’s mouth wide and breathe in air.
column7: The child yawned and stretched her arms before going to bed for the night.

column6: If something is adjoining, it is next to or joined with a building or room.
column7: I couldn’t sleep because the people in the adjoining room were loud.

column6: To allege something is to say that it is true without offering proof.
column7: The little girl had alleged that her older brother hid her favorite doll.

column6: An arch is a curved opening formed under a structure such as a bridge or doorway.
column7: The arch of the bridge was not high enough for the tall boat to pass underneath.

column6: To assemble means to get together in one place.
column7: The parents assembled to discuss ways to improve their children’s education.

column6: A casualty is a person killed or injured in a war or an accident.
column7: The only casualty in the car accident was a woman who broke her arm.

column6: To erect something means to build it.
column7: The king erected two towers on the north and south sides of his castle.

column6: If something is foul, then it is very unpleasant.
column7: He wouldn’t let his dog drink from the water because it had a foul smell.

column6: A hectare is a unit of measure equal to 10,000 square meters.
column7: His family farm covered many hectares.

column6: To heighten an emotion means to increase the intensity of it.
column7: The pleasant music heightened their enjoyment of the wonderful dinner.

column6: Hospitality is friendly behavior and entertainment, shown to guests or strangers.
column7: The travelers were amazed at the hospitality given them by the hotel’s staff.

column6: A mansion is a large and expensive home.
column7: The mansion had thirty bedrooms, two kitchens, and a pool.

column6: To outnumber a group means to have a greater number than it.
column7: The girls outnumbered the boys at the school by four to one.

column6: If someone is overjoyed, then they are extremely happy.
column7: He was overjoyed by the news of his promotion.

column6: A pasture is an area of land covered with grass for animals to use as food.
column7: The sheep were taken to a pasture where there was more grass.

column6: A petition is a written request asking an authority to do something.
column7: The citizens all signed a petition asking the mayor to repair the sidewalks.

column6: To renovate a building means to repair it, or to build new structures on it.
column7: The old fire station was renovated into an apartment building.

column6: To revise something means to change it, or update it to make it better.
column7: When the editor discovered certain facts were wrong, he revised the book.

column6: A slab is a large, thick, flat piece of stone, concrete, metal, or wood.
column7: I looked at various slabs of stone to decorate my house.

column6: A terrace is an open area that is connected to a house or an apartment.
column7: In the afternoons, she liked to sit on the terrace and check her email.

column6: Turf is a section of grass and the dirt in which it grows.
column7: After the game, the turf looked ragged.

column6: If something is analogous to another thing, then it is like it in certain ways.
column7: The relationship with his teacher was analogous to that of a son and mother.

column6: Binoculars are a device used for seeing things that are far away.
column7: He could see the ship on the horizon only if he used his binoculars.

column6: The bulk of something is its size.
column7: The large elephant moved its bulk with legs as strong as tree trunks.

column6: If something comprises something else, it consists of or is made up of it.
column7: Our school’s football team is mostly comprised with seniors.

column6: To depict something means to show or portray it, often using art.
column7: The statue’s face depicted the general’s determination and courage.

column6: If something is dual, then it is made up of two parts.
column7: The room had a dual function. It was a living room, but at night it was a bedroom.

column6: Fahrenheit is a temperature scale where water freezes at 32° and boils at 212°.
column7: When the temperature dropped to 32° Fahrenheit, it started snowing.

column6: To fulfill something means to achieve or finish it.
column7: The professor did not fulfill his promise not to miss a single class.

column6: A grove is a small group of trees.
column7: All the trees in this grove are apple trees.

column6: Ore is the raw form of rock or material from which a valuable metal is taken.
column7: The factory melted the ore and used it to make iron products.

column6: The outback is the wild inland region of Australia where very few people live.
column7: Many Australian farmers use the outback to raise cattle.

column6: To outweigh something means to exceed it in value, amount, or importance.
column7: Finding a warm place to sleep outweighed the need to find something to eat.

column6: A paradox is a true statement or real event that seems illogical.
column7: The paradox of her work was that the less she worked, the more she got done.

column6: A pier is a structure that extends into a body of water.
column7: If you want to catch bigger fish, then go to the far end of the pier.

column6: A shortcut is a route that is shorter than the main route.
column7: We got to the house early because we took a shortcut through the forest.

column6: A tariff is a tax or fee paid on certain imports or exports.
column7: Our tariff on imported wool makes foreign wool more expensive.

column6: A thermometer is a device that measures temperature.
column7: The thermometer outside the window indicated that it was a hot day today.

column6: To tilt something means to tip it into a sloping position.
column7: She tilted her glass and almost spilled some of the wine inside.

column6: If a statement is vice versa, then its two main ideas are switched with one another.
column7: Students learn from their teachers, and vice versa.

column6: The whereabouts of someone or something is the place where they are.
column7: The police looked for the lost dog, but its whereabouts were still unknown.
